10.text:
We're here in the British Library, the home
of several of Jane Austen's manuscripts.

14.text:
Jane Austen is the first novelist for whom we have
a substantial body of manuscript remains,

21.text:
ranging from fair copies of teenage writings,
through to manuscript drafts of experimental

28.text:
or aborted novels and the novel she was writing
in the year she died.

34.text:
Writers not only reveal themselves in their
choice of materials, they also reveal themselves

39.text:
in the way they use their materials. The first
thing you notice when you look at one of Jane

44.text:
Austen's draft manuscripts in these tiny booklets,
is how densely she filled the writing surface.

53.text:
Right from the very start, she starts at the
top, she leaves no margins on either side,

59.text:
she leaves very little space between the lines
- and she just writes forward continuously.

67.text:
It's as though she already has a sense of
what she wants to say and that this is firmly

72.text:
in place before she begins to write. If she
does indeed need to go back and correct, she

79.text:
squeezes in the corrections in the very small
interlinear space.

84.text:
You can also see from Jane Austen's manuscripts,
patterns of composition and development. One

91.text:
of the things that you see time and time again,
is that when she reaches a point where the

96.text:
characters are in conversation, her hand runs
smoothly - often without a pause, often without

103.text:
a mistake, often without a slip or correction.
In other passages where she's setting up a

109.text:
scene or introducing a new character and having
to describe him with some detail - before

117.text:
he actually becomes animated by conversation
- those are the passages she struggles with.

122.text:
But she does come through in the manuscripts
as essentially and most confidently a conversational

129.text:
novelist. She doesn't use paragraphs - or
very very rarely. Her favourite punctuation

136.text:
mark is a dash. She tends to avoid what we
think of as correct, grammatical punctuation

145.text:
- so when she's not using a dash, she’ll
happily use a whole series of commas and then

151.text:
eventually a full stop - usually followed
by a dash.

155.text:
This rather sits at odds with what we're told
about her as a polished stylist. It's also

163.text:
much closer to the way that we might use punctuation,
especially in our e-mail culture.
